In  the early 1980s, I was the Stage Development Engineer for the Peacekeeper (MX) ICBM Stage IV.  At one point, we switched propellant tanks on the stage from positive expulsion to surface tension tanks.  One critical part of that was characterizing the dynamic effect of propellant slosh on the stage, which did a LOT of maneuvering.  That's when I got to fly on the NASA KC-135 - the one where all of the astronauts trained, and where they filmed the zero-G scenes in "Apollo 13."   Yeah, it was absolutely the most fun I've ever had in my life.  It was a kick seeing you experience it, and having as much fun as I did!  (As an aside, my best friend and roommate from college went to work at NASA/Glenn, doing variable G combustion research.  He has the most hours of anyone on the KC-135 after Bob Williams, the guy who ran the operation.)

When I was a pilot in training, we students had to learn spin recovery.  We had to cut the engines back to idle, then execute an uncoordinated turn.  When the airplane would slow to the extent that the wings were not producing lift, the plane would literally fall out of the sky.  When that happened, the plane would go nose down, and spin round and round as it fell.  If we were not using our seat belt or harness we'd float up out of our seat.  Then we'd have to execute the spin recovery procedure.  But for a short time, it was like being weightlessm or in zero gravity.  It was kinda scary, but fun, evoking a laugh when it was done,

Since earths gravity is only negligible at around 120,000 ft, aren't you still under the full effects of gravity. Wouldn't that just be considered a variable approximation of gravitational parity during free fall? I'm not any sort of scientist, but this is my layman's understanding. edit: Piqued my curiosity, so I read up a bit, my concept of gravity/effect was rather off... pull is only affected by a small percentage relative to distance, not decreased TO that amount. So zero G is an illusion, as far as literalism is concerned, so it IS essentially perpetual free fall. Cool, old dog learning new tricks, thanks!

I really hope we get LEO travel cheap enough that you can go and spend real time in microgravity. This is a good video, you are doing quite a bit in 20 second increments of 0 g, but I really want to see w hat happens when someone on a youtuber budget can get into orbit and stay there for a couple days.



Right now, getting into orbit is super expensive, so we have to focus our orbital dollars on getting the best research possible out of it. And unfortunately, research is kind of boring. The day to day on the ISS is important, but the time it takes to digest the interesting results are a lot less than the time it takes to gather that data and do the analysis.



I'm looking forward to the video you can do in the next 5 or so years where you get to go up there and take your time, set up demonstrations, execute them, fail, tweak the methodology, get it right, get it on film, and bring it back for all of us. I look forward even more to when we can all go up there for a vacation just to mess around. Until then, this is great, keep up the good work.

Back in the 80's when there was actual room on planes and before 9/11. I loved to fly.
I would actually walk around the plane and talk to people who looked a little nervous about flying and before they knew it the flight was over. One time this big Marine I was sitting next to was white as a ghost. I asked if he was OK, He said he hated flying. I told him, You see that light on the end of the wing, He said yes, I said you only need to worry if you can't see it. If Looks could kill, I said common with me. He and I went back to the emergency exit and sat down on the floor in front of a couple ordered drinks I bought and started talking. The next thing you knew we were getting ready to land. The Marine said he really hated me after the wing joke but really liked me taking his mind off the flight by introducing him to the couple we talked with.

The best zero G experience I could get was in our little Cessna 172. I read about the Vomit Comet and copied the flightpath and watched the unfastened objects float around in the cabin. I, of course, was strapped in and could not float around, but it was fun nevertheless.

I always thought about taking out all of the seats except for the pilot's seat and letting someone else have some fun, but the cabin it cramped and there is not much space to move around in.

The Cessna 172 model has never experienced an inflight structural failure according to the NTSB, so I figured it was well strong enough for it. Zero gravity is well within the operational envelope of the 172, but it speeds up quickly in the dive and gets close to the Vne of 174 mph in no time flat.

Almost forgot to add, the day I was practicing zero G, we had record high pressure in the area and I was able to climb to 10,000 ft in just about no time at all. It was truly an amazing, clear, and smooth day.

More g forces than in the space shuttle? At takeoff they only accelerate at 1.5g, climbing to 2.5 g's just before SRB burnout at 2 minutes. At that point acceleration drops to .9 g's (just enough at that altitude to prevent losing velocity). After that the shuttle slowly accelerated up to 3g acceleration at 7 minutes after launch, which it maintained for a full minute in the upper atmosphere, just before main engine cutoff.

My idea involved that super clear putty (not ferro), sculpted into a sphere with a magnet in the middle. The sphere's radius would be the distance that magnetic field extended to. Skydiving you only get a little 'light' right at exit (from airplanes anyway) because your moving out into horizontally fast moving air; and begin to instantly decelerate (horizontally) as you start accelerating vertically. Once you reach terminal velocity (see Wikipedia), your not weightless at all... as experienced in the wind tunnel. Far as exits from hovering helicopters and balloon's go, your for all practical purposes weightless until you develop a little air speed... but said time period is very short.
Hyoscine, the drug you took to not vomit, is a hallucinogen, which in lower doses can heighten euphoria (hence the "wow"'s)
